Issues.Title: Event Binding Syntax Error Not Caught by Compiler
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? compiler ### Is this a regression? No ### Description When there is a space or an unintended newline in the event binding syntax within an Angular template, it results in a cryptic runtime error: `ERROR DOMException: Failed to execute 'setAttribute' on 'Element': '(' is not a valid attribute name.` This error message is not helpful in identifying the actual issue, which is a misplaced space or newline in the event binding syntax. The Angular compiler should ideally catch such syntax errors during the build process and provide a more descriptive error message to help developers quickly identify and fix the issue. As this example shows: `
` The Angular compiler should detect and flag the incorrect syntax for event binding during the build process. A more descriptive error message should be provided, such as: ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-zyuyay?file=src%2Fmain.ts ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true core.mjs:11483 ERROR DOMException: Failed to execute 'setAttribute' on 'Element': '(' is not a valid attribute name. at EmulatedEncapsulationDomRenderer2.setAttribute (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:134992:10) at BaseAnimationRenderer.setAttribute (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:133970:19) at setUpAttributes (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:53138:18) at setupStaticAttributes (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:59586:5) at …µ…µelementStart (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:67821:3) at Module.…µ…µelement (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:67892:3) at TrisetComponent_ng_container_0_Template (http://localhost:4200/main.js:11206:60) at executeTemplate (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:63689:9) at renderView (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:64833:7) at createAndRenderEmbeddedLView (http://localhost:4200/vendor.js:75311:3) ``` ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 18.0.7 Node: 18.20.3 Package Manager: npm 10.2.3 OS: linux x64 Angular: 18.0.6 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... platform-browser, router Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1800.7 @angular-devkit/build-angular 18.0.7 @angular-devkit/core 18.0.7 @angular-devkit/schematics 18.0.7 @angular/cli 18.0.7 @schematics/angular 18.0.7 rxjs 7.8.1 typescript 5.4.5 zone.js 0.14.7 ``` ### Anything else? This error is particularly hard to debug, especially in large templates with lots of bindings. When working on a file that contains many HTML tags, identifying the misplaced space or newline requires reading through the HTML elements one by one, which is time-consuming and error-prone. In scenarios where the component is being nested, it becomes even more challenging to see every child component and read through the HTML to find the error. A more descriptive error message would significantly improve the developer experience by making it easier to identify and fix the issue.

Issues.Title: setting autoDetectChanges to false explicitly changes the fixture behavior
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

As far as I understand, a `ComponentFixture` has two ways of working: with, or without changes auto-detection.

In reality, setting `autoDetectChanges` to `false` (even though it's supposed to already be `false` by default) has the same (partial) effect as setting it to `true`.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-uxmdfx?file=repro%2Fsrc%2Fapp%2Ffoo%2Ffoo.component.spec.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

In the above repro, you'll find three similar tests, for an OnPush component.
- the first one doesn't call `fixture.autoDetechChanges()` at all (so it leaves it to false)
- the second one call `fixture.autoDetechChanges(false)`
- the third one call `fixture.autoDetechChanges(true)`

My expectation is that the second one should pass: it should behave exactly like the first one, because setting autoDetectChanges to false when it's already false (by default) shouldn't change anything.

But the second one fails for the same reason as the third one.

You can run the repro by doing 

```
cd repro
npm i
ng test
```

Issues.Title: Easier union type narrowing in Angular control statements ('in' / `typeof` operator)
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

compiler, core

### Description

If I have a union of types i.e. `{ one: number } | { two: number } | { three: number }`, it can be a bit onerous to narrow the type in my actual template description.

Attempting to write the template exactly as I might in a pure typescript file,

```
@if('one' in obj) {
    {{ obj.one }}
}
```
results in
```
Parser Error: Unexpected token 'in' at column 10 in ['one' in obj] in ...
```

[The documentation](https://angular.dev/guide/templates/binding#syntax) does mention these operators are not supported, but chalks it up to side effects when these operators are pure.

> You can't use JavaScript expressions that have or promote side effects, including:
> * Assignments (=, +=, -=, ...)
> * Operators such as new, typeof, or instanceof
> * Chaining expressions with ; or ,
> * The increment and decrement operators ++ and --
> * Some of the ES2015+ operators

Naturally, I could write out a type predicate `function hasOne(obj: object): obj is { one: number}` on my class, but this is a little verbose and can lead to a component having many such functions.

### Proposed solution

If / else control expressions support `in` / `typeof` / `instanceof` operators like the other standard algebraic comparison operations.

### Alternatives considered

Helper function like `$any()` that apply the proper type narrowing.

Do not throw errors for accessing property if one member of union contains that property.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Easier union type narrowing in Angular control statements ('in' / `typeof` operator)" (#56875)

Search terms: _FormGroup not assignable_, _TS2322_, _2322_

When a typed reactive form requires data from a service, it cannot be created in the constructor. Rather, we need to declare the form in the component and separately instantiate it after the constructor has run, usually in the ngOnInit hook.

Separating the declaration steps from the initialization step can lead to the two types misaligning, which causes an error like the following:

```
Type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }>' is not assignable to type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }>'.
  Types of property 'controls' are incompatible.
    Type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }' is not assignable to type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }'.(2322)
```

[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-4ld5bn?file=src%2Fmain.ts)

This is a small example, but already it gets hard to parse. The issue is that one of the form controls wasn‚Äôt marked as nonNullable during initialization, and `FormControl<string|null>` is not assignable to `FormControl<string>`. Now imagine you have a Form with multiple levels of nested FormArrays and FormGroups and one control is out of sync with its declaration. It is a nightmare to debug.

### Proposed solution

When a FormGroup instance is not assignable to a variable of FormType, the error message should indicate the paths of the offending control(s) in both the instantiated and declared types. This could be done similarly to how TypeScript handles incompatible structured types:

```typescript
type Declaration = {
    a: string
    b: {
        b1: string
    }
}

type Instantiation = {
    a: string
    b: {
        b1: string | null
    }
}

let decl: Declaration
let inst!: Instantiation

decl = inst
```

```
Type 'Instantiation' is not assignable to type 'Declaration'.
  The types of 'b.b1' are incompatible between these types.
    Type 'string | null' is not assignable to type 'string'.
      Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'string'.(2322)
```
[TS Playground](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play/?#code/C4TwDgpgBAIhDGAbAhgJ2cAlgewHZQF4oBvAWACgoqpkAuKAZ2FU1wHMLqoAjesyrtW4BGekxbtO1AL4VZ5CqEhQAkribJcWDDnxF+XOo2asOAqrxJTBPUcYlsoAHyi4ArokTWo8+RUQQwFAAJgiI9HBIaDp4-oFQrEwAhPRqGlqYMbgUFKFIhAnqwEA)

I say ‚Äúin both the instantiated and declared types‚Äù to catch the case where one type has more form controls than the other ‚Äì this case is handled by this error message in TS:

```
Property 'b' is missing in type 'Instantiation' but required in type 'Declaration'.(2741)
```

When two form controls differ in type, then the error message should unwrap the types of the controls and explain why they‚Äôre not assignable. In the example above, this might look like this:

```
Type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }>' is not assignable to type 'FormGroup<{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }>'.
  Types of property 'controls' are incompatible.
    Type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string | null>; }' is not assignable to type '{ a: FormControl<string>; b: FormControl<string>; c: FormControl<string>; }'.
       The types of 'c' are incompatible between these types.
         Type 'string | null' is not assignable to type 'string'.
           Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'string'.(2322)
```

### Alternatives considered

None.

        return true;
    }
    return false;
}
```

i have my custom builder name there.

I might be missing something here, but there is no documentation for these cases. As I am not an expert, it has been quite challenging to understand how this should work. I would greatly appreciate any help you can provide!

Thank you in advance for your assistance.

Issues.Title: Allow creating git local user with new project before making first commit
Issues.Body:
### Command

new

### Description

I need to keep multiple git identities on my computer. When creating `ng new` I need to have control over which identity is used to create the project, as I don't always want to use the `--global` git user. I often forget run into situations where I create a new project with wrong identity.


### Describe the solution you'd like

The solution I'd prefer would be some sort of micro-routine that would allow creating local project `user.*` config and then make the initial commit utilizing it, without the need of using the commit skipping flag.

Imagine this syntax (just an example):

  `ng new --git-local-user` or `ng new -G`

The script creates a new project, but before it gets to making git commit, it shows a radio-button menu:
```
(*) create local git user
( ) use global git user (abcxyz)
```

Selecting create would prompt for user name and then user email and once done, make the first commit as it would normally do.


### Describe alternatives you've considered

You can either:

1. `--commit false` and then manually: create local user, `git add .`, `git commit` 
2. Erase `git config --global user.*` entries to deliberately make the git fail, but this is kind of harsh

None of those offers nice Dx.

With just one new flag you'd get a nice and consistent cli behavior and would get the entire flow with some extra git helper routine.

***This release deliberately contains backwards-incompatible changes.*** To avoid automatically picking up releases like this, you should either be pinning the exact version of `esbuild` in your `package.json` file (recommended) or be using a version range syntax that only accepts patch upgrades such as `^0.22.0` or `~0.22.0`. See npm's documentation about [semver](https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v6/using-npm/semver/) for more information.

-   Revert the recent change to avoid bundling dependencies for node ([#​3819](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3819))

    This release reverts the recent change in version 0.22.0 that made `--packages=external` the default behavior with `--platform=node`.  The default is now back to `--packages=bundle`.

    I've just been made aware that Amazon doesn't pin their dependencies in their "AWS CDK" product, which means that whenever esbuild publishes a new release, many people (potentially everyone?) using their SDK around the world instantly starts using it without Amazon checking that it works first. This change in version 0.22.0 happened to break their SDK. I'm amazed that things haven't broken before this point. This revert attempts to avoid these problems for Amazon's customers. Hopefully Amazon will pin their dependencies in the future.

    In addition, this is probably a sign that esbuild is used widely enough that it now needs to switch to a more complicated release model. I may have esbuild use a beta channel model for further development.

-   Fix preserving collapsed JSX whitespace ([#​3818](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3818))

    When transformed, certain whitespace inside JSX elements is ignored completely if it collapses to an empty string. However, the whitespace should only be ignored if the JSX is being transformed, not if it's being preserved. This release fixes a bug where esbuild was previously incorrectly ignoring collapsed whitespace with `--jsx=preserve`. Here is an example:

    ```jsx
    // Original code
    <Foo>
      <Bar />
    </Foo>

    // Old output (with --jsx=preserve)
    <Foo><Bar /></Foo>;

    // New output (with --jsx=preserve)
    <Foo>
      <Bar />
    </Foo>;
    ```

Issues.Title: Add support for esbuild chunkNames option
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

The application builder does not provide all the options esbuild does ; I think the possibility to customize further the output location is interesting though.

As esbuild propose options to control the file names of automatically generated chunks (https://esbuild.github.io/api/#chunk-names), it could be a nice addition of options available through the application builder schema.

The same strategy could maybe be applied with similar `assetNames` option.

### Describe the solution you'd like

To be able to control it for all chunks, I guess a good location for this templating string would be in the `outputPath` object like

```json
{
  "build": {
    "executor": "",            
    "options": {
      "outputPath": {
        "base": "dist",
        "browser": "prod",
        "server": "server",
        "media": "media",
        "browserChunkNames": "front-[ext]/[name]_[hash]",
        "serverChunkNames": "example--[hash]"
      },
  ...
  }
}
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I'm currently using the application builder via the @nx/angular:application that, in addition of the cli builder features, add the suport of providing esbuild plugins.

Unfortunately I didn't manage to find or write a plugin that can infer on the generated files, issues are open on this subject on esbuild to have callbacks such as "onEmit" for instance but as there is an existing option for the scenario, better use it.

Thanks for reading.

Issues.Title: Reduce angular uses of file watcher by leveraging folder watcher (ex: ng serve)
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Description

I keep reaching the ENOSPC watcher errors with angular.

It would be nice for angular `ng serve` to be less ressource hungry by reusing folder watchers instead of file watchers. This would also reduce the need for "file watch filtering".

### Describe the solution you'd like

According to inotify man page angular watcher could use folder watches instead of watching file reducing the amount of watcher greatly (reusing a single inotify watcher per watched folder instead of one watcher file actual file).

The code would have to do the actual filtering on event reception to known if the item was watched (the event includes a file `name` attribute for folder watch allowing to known which file changed).

```
NAME         [top](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/inotify.7.html#top_of_page)
       inotify - monitoring filesystem events
DESCRIPTION         [top](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/inotify.7.html#top_of_page)
       The inotify API provides a mechanism for monitoring filesystem
       events.  Inotify can be used to monitor individual files, or to
       monitor directories.  When a directory is monitored, inotify will
       return events for the directory itself, and for files inside the
       directory.

[...]

The name field is present only when an event is returned for a
       file inside a watched directory; it identifies the filename
       within the watched directory.  This filename is null-terminated,
       and may include further null bytes ('\0') to align subsequent
       reads to a suitable address boundary.
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

The suggested alternative on the internet is to increase the sysctl limit for watchers at the cost of a kernel memory usage increase.

Issues.Title: bug(MatCheckbox/MatSlideToggle): the component is included in the form control validators when using Reactive Forms
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

I don't know if this behavior was present in previous versions, but I'm sure it happens in Angular v17 as well because that's where I first reproduced it.

### Description

When using `MatCheckbox` or `MatSlideToggle` with Reactive Forms (let's say we are using it with a `FormControl` named `control`), when one inspects `control.validator` it always contains an array with at least one validation function, even if `control` has no validator defined.

If we set a breakpoint in the `_setValidators` method of `AbstractControlDirective` we will see that it receives an instance of `_MatCheckbox`/`MatSlideToggle` (see screenshot).

![debugger](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/38230545/a1379572-e219-4648-8938-6d65d6c74eee)

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-xpcrvu
Steps to reproduce:
1. Check the console logs to verify what is described in the description.


### Expected Behavior

`checkboxControl.validator` and `slideToggleControl.validator` must be `null`.

### Actual Behavior

`checkboxControl.validator`/`slideToggleControl.validator` are `[compose(control) { ... }]` (after the view has been initialized) when using `MatCheckbox`/`MatSlideToggle` with `FormControlDirective`.

### Environment

```
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1800.6
@angular-devkit/build-angular   18.0.6
@angular-devkit/core            18.0.6
@angular-devkit/schematics      18.0.6
@angular/cli                    18.0.6
@schematics/angular             18.0.6
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.4.5
zone.js                         0.14.7
```
